posts.name: Caden
posts.cooked:
We are trying to run an auto program.  We are using Path Planner and the path is a straight line. We followed the steps on the PathPlanner docs, but are still having issues. Our turning motors are aligning straight  (which should happen), but the drive motors jerk back and forth. Could anyone help us find the problem and a possible resolution? Thanks!

github code: GitHub - CorpuzIhate/6110_Maestro_brokenAuto_03_08 (Missing certain files, and not organized like this in our real code due to technical difficulties) image 1898×1022 73.5 KB

image 1898×1022 73.5 KB

image 1898×1022 73.5 KB

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: have you tuned your translation PID gains?

posts.name: Rex Hoskinson
posts.cooked: We had a similar issue. Is the bot oscillating once reaching the end of the path or jerking back and forth without getting closer to the target? If it’s doing the first one, you probably have issues with translation PID gains like @Gandagorn suggested. If it’s the second, could still be a PID issue or a problem with velocity gains if you’re using velocity control. We ended up abandoning pathplanner for this season because we had a ton of other issues. If your auto doesn’t need to be too advanced, you can always skip pathplanner and just PID the bot to an odometry position.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Could Be Better, Could Be Worse

posts.custom_user_title: Could Be Better, Could Be Worse

posts.name: Caden
posts.cooked: We turned down the pid to 0.5 as it was at 5 (as given in the pathplanner docs ) for both drive pid and turning pid. After a power cycle the robot was still jerking back and forth practically on the spot. We ran that same auto again right after, it started jerking less violently but the robot still wasnt going anywhere.

posts.name: Caden
posts.cooked: Its jerking back and forth  and not reaching the target. We want to use pathplanner because of how easy it is to create new paths. We plan on having a 2-3 note auto.

posts.name: Rex Hoskinson
posts.cooked: Are you giving your swerve modules a target velocity or power? Velocity control has been giving us trouble because the built-in velocity measurements from the sparkmax is unreliable.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Could Be Better, Could Be Worse

posts.custom_user_title: Could Be Better, Could Be Worse

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
It sounds like your velocity PID gains are too high. When that happens, the drive velocity will overshoot the setpoint and try to correct itself, resulting in a back and forth motion without any translation.

I see your turning PID controller in SwerveModule.java but I don’t see where you are setting your drive PID controller. Could you point to where you are setting your drive speed as @RexHoskinson suggested?

posts.name: Skyler Brennan
posts.cooked:
(I’m on the Same team as the poster)

The PID tuner in the swerve sub under “AutoBuilder.configureHolomic” and “HolonomicPathFollowerConfig”

The 1st and 2nd parameter are the translation and rotation PID constants.

But it’s not even moving to the destination which seems weird. It’s just jerking back and forth on the spot.

posts.name: Skyler Brennan
posts.cooked:
We set the drive speed for the auto config under the “driveRobotRelative” method. It takes a robot relative chassis speed and sets our module states.

Then if u look under SwerveModule.java, the set Desired state method is there.

posts.name: Rex Hoskinson
posts.cooked:
iirc the issue you’re having is more likely to do with how you’re setting individual drive motors to target velocities (at least that’s what my team’s issue was). Even if the target chassis speed is correct the resulting motion won’t be if your drive motors are oscillating when trying to PID to a target velocity.

Edit: Can’t see your code on school wifi, so I could be wrong. Not sure if you’re giving motors a value for power or a specific velocity to maintain.

posts.custom_user_title: Could Be Better, Could Be Worse

posts.name: Caden
posts.cooked: The oscillations were less violent but it was not moving anywhere

posts.name: Caden
posts.cooked: From what we know, driveRobotRelative is the method that eventually turns the motors. We dont know how pathplanner calculates those values or if it has a built in PID controller (the autoconfig method already takes in PID constants, so idk). The only example code online i see is with a sim and they didn’t create a PID controller for its driving. We never created a PID controller. If we were to create one, how would we implement it with PathPlanner?

posts.name: Rex Hoskinson
posts.cooked: Pathplanner handles the PID controller stuff for you. My team’s running a near-identical setup for pathplanner and it was working pretty well, so I’m not sure where else the issue could be. You’re correct about driveRobotRelative turning the motors. If it were oscillating while translating forwards I’d say it was a PID issue, but it doesn’t seem to be the case here. The only other potential issue that comes to mind is that you may need to reset your odometry values in autoInit(). Our bot had been assuming it had already reached the end of the path and wasn’t moving as a result.
